rules: Rule1: If a financial product was used for funding, then upon completion of the program by an employee, that employee becomes certified.
Rule2: Either a financial product was used for funding or an employee used personal funds.
Rule3: Provided that an employee used personal funds, if the employee completes the program, then the employee is certified.
Rule4: The alcohol policy is either violated or followed.
Rule5: Whenever the alcohol policy is followed, then having access to a facility implies that the employee does not require training for a skill.

Rule6: If a manager reported a violation of the alcohol policy, then should the alcohol policy be violated, if an employee has access to a facility, the employee does not require training for a skill.
Rule7: Either a manager reported a violation of the alcohol policy or an employee witnessed a violation of the alcohol policy.
Rule8: If an employee witnessed a violation of the alcohol policy, then HR confirmed a violation of the alcohol policy.
Rule9: Provided that HR confirmed a violation of the alcohol policy, then if the alcohol policy is violated, having access to a facility means the employee does not require training for a skill.
Rule10: If an employee has clearance for a facility, then should it not be the case that not being certified implies not completing a course on a publication, the employee is granted an exception.
Rule11: Either an employee is in an alternative program or if the employee enrolls in a program, the employee is certified.
Rule12: If an employee is in a standard program, then the employee is not in an alternative program.
Rule13: If an employee passed an assessment for a skill, then the employee did not complete a course on a publication.
Rule14: Provided that an employee attended a workshop at a facility, the employee is certified.
Rule15: If it is not the case that having access to a facility implies not requiring training for a skill, then the employee needs remedial training.
Rule16: If it is not true that enrolling in a program leads to attending a workshop at a facility, then the employee dropped out.

Rule17: Provided that it is not the case that not being in an accelerated program or having program completion imply certification leads to being in an extended program, then the employee has a program conflict.

Rule18: If it is not the case that the absence of either being in an accelerated program or program completion implying certification results in being in an extended program, then the employee does not have a program conflict.
Rule19: If an employee does not have clearance for a facility, then the employee's clearance was revoked.
Rule20: In the event that an employee does not have clearance for a facility, it is not the case that the employee's clearance was revoked.
Rule21: Whenever an employee is not certified, the employee requires training for a skill.
Rule22: Provided that an employee is not certified, the employee has access to a facility.
Rule23: If an employee is not certified, then the employee completed a course on a publication.
Rule24: In the event that an employee is not certified, the employee passed an assessment for a skill.
facts: Fact1: An employee is in a standard program.
Fact2: An employee enrolled in a program.
Fact3: An employee completed the program.
Fact4: It is not the case that an employee was granted an exception.
Fact5: An employee is not in an accelerated program.
Fact6: An employee is not in an extended program.
Fact7: It is not the case that an employee needs remedial training.
Fact8: An employee did not drop out.
